description: From Middle English lytere, litere, from Anglo-Norman litiere (modern French litière), from Medieval Latin lectaria, from Latin lectus (“bed”); compare Ancient Greek λέκτρον (léktron). Had the sense ‘bed’ in very early English, but then came to mean ‘portable couch’, ‘bedding’, ‘strewn rushes (for animals)’, etc.

entries.meaning: (countable) A platform mounted on two shafts, or a more elaborate construction, designed to be carried by two (or more) people to transport one (in luxury models sometimes more) third person(s) or (occasionally in the elaborate version) a cargo, such as a religious idol.
examples: Synonyms: palanquin, sedan chair, stretcher, cacolet

entries.meaning: (collective, countable) The offspring of a mammal born in one birth.
examples: The runt of the litter is a puppy that is the smallest or weakest among the newborn dogs in a litter .

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Material used as bedding for animals.
(uncountable) Collectively, items discarded on the ground.
examples: Synonyms: waste, rubbish, (US) garbage, (US) trash, junk

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Absorbent material used in an animal's litter tray
(uncountable) Layer of fallen leaves and similar organic matter in a forest floor.
A covering of straw for plants.

verbs.description: litter (third-person singular simple present litters, present participle littering, simple past and past participle littered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To drop or throw trash without properly disposing of it (as discarding in public areas rather than trash receptacles).
examples: By tossing the bottle out the window, he was littering.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To strew (a place) with scattered articles.
(transitive) To give birth to, used of animals.
(intransitive) To produce a litter of young.
(transitive) To supply (cattle etc.) with litter; to cover with litter, as the floor of a stall.
examples: Tell them how they litter their jades.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be supplied with litter as bedding; to sleep or make one's bed in litter.
examples: The inn where he and his horse litter'd.
